quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we cover a lot of ground, including how Calendly builds product, how Calendly has grown, including the wild story of how they got their first 1,000 users, and also how they built a sales team on top of what historically has been a very product-led growth company.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete growth milestone (first 1,000 users) and a notable shift from pure product-led growth to adding sales—useful for thinking about scaling GTM motions.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Annie also shares a ton of great advice on how to get into product management.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Signals that the episode includes actionable career guidance for aspiring PMs.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: For example, with Miro, you can plan out next quarter's entire product strategy.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical workflow suggestion: using a collaborative whiteboard to structure product strategy planning.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Then your whole distributed team can come together around wire frames, drive ideas with a pen tool, and then put full mocks right into the Miro board.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Describes an end-to-end collaboration method for distributed product teams—from early concepts to high-fidelity mocks in one shared space.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: More recently, I actually wrote a whole post on how Coda's product team operates. And within that post, they shared a dozen templates that they use internally to run their product team, including managing the roadmap, their OKR process, getting internal feedback, and essentially their whole product development process is done within Koda.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific example of operationalizing product management with reusable templates across roadmap, OKRs, and feedback loops.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's a great shared space to capture ideas, get feedback, and collaborate with your colleagues on anything that you're working on.
quotes.speaker: Speaker
quotes.context: A concise, reusable articulation of what makes a collaboration space valuable in day-to-day team work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: For example, with Miro, you can plan out next quarter's entire product strategy.
quotes.speaker: Speaker
quotes.context: A concrete example of using a single collaborative artifact to drive strategic planning, not just brainstorming.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can start by brainstorming, using sticky notes, live reactions, a voting tool, even an estimation app to scope out your team's sprints.
quotes.speaker: Speaker
quotes.context: An actionable workflow that moves from ideation to prioritization to sprint scoping using specific tools.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I use Coda every day to wrangle my newsletter content calendar, my interview notes for podcasts, and to coordinate my sponsors.
quotes.speaker: Speaker
quotes.context: A specific, practical set of use cases showing how one system can replace scattered docs for operational coordination.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Koda puts data in one centralized location regardless of format, eliminating roadblocks that can slow your team down.
quotes.speaker: Speaker
quotes.context: A clear operational principle: centralize cross-format information to reduce friction and execution delays.

quotes.topic_title: How to share Calendly without awkwardness
quotes.text: But I think that at a high level, I think I recommend first really just kind of opening the door for the person you're trying to schedule time with to share their availability first.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A simple etiquette-first approach that reduces the “power move” feeling by giving the recipient the first move.

quotes.topic_title: How to share Calendly without awkwardness
quotes.text: So instead of just sending the link, I usually start the email with something like looking forward to connecting, feel free to share, sometimes you're available or if easier, you can choose to find time on my calendar using the Calendly link here.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Provides copy-and-pasteable wording that offers choice and makes the Calendly link feel optional rather than imposed.

quotes.topic_title: How to share Calendly without awkwardness
quotes.text: And the second piece I would recommend too is once you opened that door, you can further reduce the effort on the recipient by adding times you're available directly in the email.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A friction-reduction tactic that minimizes steps for the recipient and increases the chance of booking.

quotes.topic_title: How to share Calendly without awkwardness
quotes.text: So, when you go to share a Calendly link, there's an option to add times to email and you can then just paste those directly into the email you're creating, so that reduces yet another sort of point of friction to ask the user to click the link and get taken to Calendly.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A specific product workflow practitioners can use immediately to make scheduling faster without requiring a link click.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management from nontraditional roles
quotes.text: But when I think about folks who are looking to get in their product management, I think there's really two paths. I think one is more formal in nature.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: She introduces a simple framework (formal vs. informal) for breaking into product management from nontraditional roles.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management from nontraditional roles
quotes.text: There are associate product manager programs out there and many scaled companies, Google, Meta. All have APM programs that you can formally apply to.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A concrete, actionable entry path: apply to APM programs at scaled companies as a structured on-ramp into PM.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management from nontraditional roles
quotes.text: And actually, when we were at Box, much earlier stage company than either of those companies I just mentioned, we actually created an APM program to help grow our bench of more junior PM.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A specific example that challenges the assumption APM programs only exist in big tech and suggests looking at smaller companies too.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management from nontraditional roles
quotes.text: I think on the informal side, really two suggestions here. The first one is to seek out opportunities to shadow or partner closely with a product manager and maybe even offer to take on some work.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A practical playbook for internal transitions: start doing PM-adjacent work by shadowing/partnering before formally switching roles.

quotes.topic_title: Breaking into product management from nontraditional roles
quotes.text: And then maybe last one is just the path I did, which is joining an early stage startup. There's really usually an expectation that everyone's going to get their hands dirty doing a lot of different things.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A counterintuitive route into PM: use early-stage startups’ “wear many hats” reality to get real PM experience without the title.

quotes.topic_title: Which PM transition paths work best
quotes.text: Yeah, I've brought a lot of folks over internally for the path of someone's really interested in product, they express they're interested, they want to help, they want to learn, they're eager, they're curious. And so, they make that really well known and they're even willing to do some work on the side to help out and really show and demonstrate the skills before they have the job. So, I've seen that one to actually probably bring the most folks over in my role in terms of being on the product leadership side.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A concrete internal-transfer playbook: signal interest early and prove capability by doing real product work before you have the title.

quotes.topic_title: Which PM transition paths work best
quotes.text: It may be better to try and find a company like Box or a company that's a bit earlier stage, not as scaled to think about looking at those APM programs.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Counterintuitive career advice: targeting less-scaled companies can be a more realistic and effective path into PM than only chasing marquee APM programs.

quotes.topic_title: Which PM transition paths work best
quotes.text: And I'm sure if you want to, go to glassdoor.com where I used to work at Glassdoor, so had to throw that in there. You could search for associate product manager and I think you'll find a whole host of open roles that you might be able to apply to.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A practical tactic for finding entry-level PM roles: use a targeted job-title search to discover APM openings across companies.

quotes.topic_title: Which PM transition paths work best
quotes.text: The other thing I would say is when I think about folks who have successfully transferred over, I think they tend to have a couple of characteristics. They're usually very curious, they tend to be really passionate about the product and solving customer problems. And sometimes, they've even tinkered with a side project as a way to hone their PM skills.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A clear set of signals that predict successful PM transitions: curiosity, customer-problem focus, and side projects that build PM skill.

quotes.topic_title: Why APM programs are rare and hard
quotes.text: Yeah, I think when we built this at Box, so drawing on that experience, it was a lot of work.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Grounds the rarity of APM programs in real operational cost, not lack of interest or belief in the concept.

quotes.topic_title: Why APM programs are rare and hard
quotes.text: If you're going to do it, you want to do it really well and you want to create an environment where you can help the associate product managers be successful, the goal is to ultimately graduate everyone from the APM program into being a product manager.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Defines a clear success metric for APM programs: designing the program around graduation into PM roles.

quotes.topic_title: Why APM programs are rare and hard
quotes.text: We had to make sure we had clarity around the interview process. We had to make sure we had clarity around expectations in the role. We wanted to have a training element.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Provides a practical checklist of the core building blocks required to run an APM program effectively.

quotes.topic_title: Why APM programs are rare and hard
quotes.text: So, I think companies have to be at a stage of scale where they can really invest and they have the excess capacity to build the program in a way.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive constraint: APM programs are often a “luxury” enabled by scale and spare capacity, not just good intentions.

quotes.topic_title: Why APM programs are rare and hard
quotes.text: So, I think there's a lot of ancillary activities around the actual program itself that have to be taken into consideration to make sure that it is actually very successful.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Warns that the hidden work (design choices, promotion, internal vs external scope) is what often makes programs fail to launch or underperform.

quotes.topic_title: Calendly product org scale and structure
quotes.text: Let's see, when I joined about two years ago, I think the company was about 150 people and I think we're about 600 now. And then the product team, there were about 15 product managers and designers when I joined again about two years ago, and I think we're around 60 this year.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Concrete scaling data points for overall company growth and the product/design org’s expansion.

quotes.topic_title: Calendly product org scale and structure
quotes.text: And then, on my product leadership team, we have head of design, head of research, head of product operations. And then, within the product management team, I have leaders across core, across enterprise and platform.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A clear org-structure snapshot showing how Calendly groups leadership across functions and product areas.

quotes.topic_title: Calendly product org scale and structure
quotes.text: I think at the end of the day, the real benefit of the structure is really to say at the end, we want to be thinking about everything we're doing through the lens of the end-to-end user experience.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A guiding principle for why product, design, and research can sit under one leader: optimize for end-to-end UX.

quotes.topic_title: Calendly product org scale and structure
quotes.text: So, if we have product managers who are really prioritizing the problems we're going to go after, and we've got designers who are really trying to think about how do we bring solutions to life to solve those problems, having both of those functions roll into one person just really allows us to think more holistically around the end-to-end user experience.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: An actionable mental model for aligning PM and design: problems (PM) + solutions (design) under one umbrella to drive holistic UX.

quotes.topic_title: Calendly product org scale and structure
quotes.text: So, one of the first leadership hires I made was to bring in a head of design to really build out that function.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A specific example of a scaling move: adding a design leader early to formalize and grow the design function.

quotes.topic_title: Team structure by persona: core, enterprise, platform
quotes.text: So, we have a core team who's really responsible for the core end to-end user experience. In many ways, they're both doing feature development and then they're also doing growth work.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Highlights a team design choice: combining product feature development and growth/PLG responsibilities under one core team to own the full user experience.

quotes.topic_title: Team structure by persona: core, enterprise, platform
quotes.text: And then growth work to think about the PLG funnel, everything from acquisition, activation, conversion, and retention.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Provides a concrete, end-to-end PLG funnel model that teams can use to scope growth ownership and metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Team structure by persona: core, enterprise, platform
quotes.text: And then, second group is our "enterprise group." And they're really thinking about two different personas. One is the IT admin, the person who needs to make sure that Calendly is secure and that they have all the reporting mechanisms to be able to manage their account and all the tools to manage users and groups at scale. And the second piece of that is also departmental leaders.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Shows a practical enterprise segmentation: designing for both centralized IT admins and decentralized department leaders with distinct needs.

quotes.topic_title: Team structure by persona: core, enterprise, platform
quotes.text: And then lastly, we have a platform team who's really thinking about how do we embed Calendly into the business processes of the organizations that we support and that we provide our product into. And so, that's everything from partnerships and integrations to our APIs.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Defines a platform team charter around embedding into workflows via integrations, partnerships, and APIs—useful for structuring platform orgs beyond “infrastructure.”

quotes.topic_title: Team structure by persona: core, enterprise, platform
quotes.text: That's right, that's right. Yeah, trying to sell it to, and then the persona of who's going to be using the functionality. And then, really having those teams hone and own those personas as they're developing functionality within the product.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Reinforces a persona-ownership operating model: align teams to both buyer and user personas and make them accountable for serving those personas end-to-end.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs maturity: from siloed to integrated planning
quotes.text: When I first joined, I'd say we didn't have this muscle well built out. We didn't really have a clear product strategy at the time or clear OKRs guiding the work. And so, there was a lot of great work happening, but it really was unclear how it all fit together or how we were going to measure success in that work.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Highlights the common failure mode where teams are busy and productive but lack alignment and measurable outcomes—making the case for strategy + OKRs as connective tissue.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs maturity: from siloed to integrated planning
quotes.text: I think the second phase for us was we developed a product strategy. We then had product team OKRs that corresponded to that product strategy, but they were really contained to the product team and each department across the organization had their own kind of siloed OKRs.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Provides a maturity model step: even with good product OKRs, execution can stall if other functions run disconnected OKRs.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs maturity: from siloed to integrated planning
quotes.text: And then, phase three, where really, I'd say we headed into this year, we have a really clear set, as I mentioned, of company OKRs and then in these really tightly integrated plans across the company around how we're going to support the key results and ultimately deliver on the objectives.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Describes the practical shift from siloed goal-setting to integrated planning tied directly to company key results.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs maturity: from siloed to integrated planning
quotes.text: And this has been a really incredible transformation of dependency mapping, being able to make sure that we're pulling all the levers across the organization to drive our most important objective.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Introduces dependency mapping as an execution methodology to coordinate cross-functional work against top objectives.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs maturity: from siloed to integrated planning
quotes.text: So, I think it's just the kind of maturing of the business from almost no OKRs to product team OKRs to now company OKRs in a really tight planning process to make sure there's a lot of integration across the company to support what we need to do as a business.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Summarizes a clear OKR maturity progression practitioners can use as a roadmap for scaling alignment and execution.

quotes.topic_title: Narrowing ICP to improve prioritization and focus
quotes.text: At any point in time, it was really difficult to say, should I do work on feature A or for feature B without that clarity?
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Shows how a broad user base creates prioritization thrash without a clearly defined target market and personas.

quotes.topic_title: Narrowing ICP to improve prioritization and focus
quotes.text: one of the most impactful things we did pretty early on in my tenure here was to hone in on our overall product strategy, but a poor piece of that being what's the actual market we're going after? What are the segments of that market? Who are the personas within the segments of that market?
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Provides a practical ICP-clarification framework: market → segments → personas to drive product strategy and prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Narrowing ICP to improve prioritization and focus
quotes.text: When in reality, the ability to say no is going to allow you to make sure you're building something that's going to be amazing for the people that matter most and not something that's going to be average or okay for a lot of different people.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A counterintuitive prioritization principle: saying no increases product quality and focus for the most important users.

quotes.topic_title: Narrowing ICP to improve prioritization and focus
quotes.text: So, when I joined Calendly, all of our ARR came from our PLG channel. We didn't have a sales team, we just hired a CRO who was going to build out a sales team.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A concrete example of a go-to-market shift (PLG to adding sales) that forces changes in ICP focus and company operating model.

quotes.topic_title: Narrowing ICP to improve prioritization and focus
quotes.text: And then, as we sort of moved up market and have now explicitly started to go after teams of users and departments of users and organizations of larger scale, everything about people, process, and product all changes.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A memorable operating-model heuristic: moving upmarket requires coordinated changes across people, process, and product.

quotes.topic_title: Calendly’s viral growth loop and PLG-to-SLG shift
quotes.text: Seventy percent of our signups come through that viral loop that you referred to.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Concrete data point quantifying how much Calendly’s growth is driven by its viral sharing loop.

quotes.topic_title: Calendly’s viral growth loop and PLG-to-SLG shift
quotes.text: And so, that's a very different profile of a sales team member than you might need after you need to pursue more of a heavy outbound motion, more of a hunter profile than a grower profile.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Actionable hiring framework: match sales hiring profiles to the current motion (inbound “grower” vs outbound “hunter”).

quotes.topic_title: Calendly’s viral growth loop and PLG-to-SLG shift
quotes.text: So, when you transition from PLG to sales led or adding this direct sales motion, the buyer is usually just the department head. It's the head of sales, it's the head of rev ops, it's the head of recruiting and it's not a senior person in IT or the CIO.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Counterintuitive buyer-persona insight: early SLG expansion from PLG often sells to functional leaders, not IT/CIO.

quotes.topic_title: Calendly’s viral growth loop and PLG-to-SLG shift
quotes.text: You wouldn't necessarily want to bring on a bunch of sales folks who are at Oracle who are heavy in selling into CIOs in the early days because that's just not who you're the buyer's going to be.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Practical hiring guidance: avoid enterprise IT-selling backgrounds early if your buyer is departmental leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Calendly’s viral growth loop and PLG-to-SLG shift
quotes.text: As I mentioned, when I joined two years ago, we just hired our first CRO and the PLG business really represented 99% of our ARR. And then, over the last two years, we've scaled the sales team in our SLG motion. Our sales led growth motion now represents about 20% of our ARR and it's actually the fastest growing segment of the business.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Specific example of a PLG-to-SLG shift with measurable impact on revenue mix and growth rate.

quotes.topic_title: Product and sales collaboration: using GTM as customer lens
quotes.text: The first piece that really starts with is customer empathy.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Frames product–sales collaboration as fundamentally about building deeper customer understanding.

quotes.topic_title: Product and sales collaboration: using GTM as customer lens
quotes.text: And at the end of the day, seeing the sales team and the go-to-market team as this really great asset that can help you as a product manager get closer to the customer.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Offers a practical mental model: treat GTM as a customer-empathy amplifier for product decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Product and sales collaboration: using GTM as customer lens
quotes.text: I've certainly seen organizations or been in organizations where the product team doesn't necessarily want to be bothered by sales, but I sort of flip that on the head and say sales and sort of the go-to-market teams in general could be your biggest asset to helping you get your job done well.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Counterintuitive advice to embrace sales as a core product asset rather than a distraction.

quotes.topic_title: Product and sales collaboration: using GTM as customer lens
quotes.text: When I was at Box, I was a product manager on the enterprise team and I spent a ton of time in the field and I don't know how I would possibly know how to have what to have built or how to build it to solve the needs of our customers if I didn't have that close relationship with the sales team and be able to lean on them because they're talking to, 10X of them were customers that I was able to ever talk to within any given week, really lean on them to be the voice of the customer to help me make the best product decisions that I could.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Concrete example and data point (“10X”) showing how sales exposure can scale customer insight for PMs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you want to sell to the enterprise, proving security is essential.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical go-to-market requirement: enterprise deals often hinge on demonstrable security posture.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: SOC 2 can either open the door for bigger and better deals or it can put your business on hold.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames SOC 2 as a gating mechanism that directly impacts revenue velocity and deal progression.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you don't have a SOC two, there's a good chance you won't even get a seat at the table.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable, high-signal warning that compliance can be a prerequisite, not a nice-to-have.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 3,000 fast-growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption and impact data point to benchmark automation leverage for compliance work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta can get you ready for security audits in weeks instead of months, less than a third of the time that it usually takes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Gives a specific time-to-value claim practitioners can use to evaluate ROI and planning timelines for SOC 2 readiness.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritization via strategy and horizons allocation
quotes.text: I think it really starts with a clear product strategy that will dictate a few things. And I like this framework that's taken from a book called Playing to Win and it talks about how strategy is really just an integrated set of choices that outline how you're going to win in whatever marketplace you choose.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Introduces a concrete strategy framework (Playing to Win) as the foundation for prioritization decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritization via strategy and horizons allocation
quotes.text: And so, what I think this framework does kind of dovetails back to what I was saying before around prioritization is it forces you to create clarity around where you're going to play and where you're not going to play.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Highlights the practical prioritization power of explicitly defining what you will not do.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritization via strategy and horizons allocation
quotes.text: Now, the year one that I was here, the percentage of resources we spent on that first horizon and the second horizon was about a 70/30 split and we put 0% of our resources on horizon three.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Gives a specific horizons-based resource allocation example practitioners can mirror in their own planning.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritization via strategy and horizons allocation
quotes.text: And then, as we're entering to year three now, we've significantly scaled back the investment in horizon one, that's about 30% and then we've got 60% in horizon two and call it 10 in horizon three.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Shows how resource allocation should evolve over time as the company scales and strategy matures.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritization via strategy and horizons allocation
quotes.text: But our target market that we're really trying to go after as our primary persona are as I've mentioned, these sort of core ICPs within organizations. So, sales teams, recruiting teams, customer success teams. And so, it doesn't make sense within those personas to pursue something like a Venmo integration.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A concrete example of deprioritizing a frequently requested feature because it doesn’t fit the ICP-driven strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Planning cadence, roadmaps, and delivery commitments
quotes.text: So, we have the company level OKRs and I mentioned that we have about three of those this year. And then, those KRs within the company, OKRs are measured annually, but we have milestones across a quarterly basis so we can measure progress more frequently than obviously on the annual or semi-annual basis.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A practical planning cadence: a small set of annual OKRs with quarterly milestones to keep measurement and course-correction frequent.

quotes.topic_title: Planning cadence, roadmaps, and delivery commitments
quotes.text: Something we've done over the last year is really kind of moved to a model of talking about dates and promising and committing to dates that are within our control.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A counterintuitive commitment model: commit to controllable phases rather than uncertain long-range delivery dates.

quotes.topic_title: Planning cadence, roadmaps, and delivery commitments
quotes.text: And so, we've gotten a lot better at making the commitments around the work that's right in front of us versus making a commitment around a project six months out when we haven't even done enough discovery, enough design and ideation to have a real clear understanding of estimation.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Clear advice on avoiding overcommitment by deferring delivery-date promises until discovery and solution clarity exist.

quotes.topic_title: Planning cadence, roadmaps, and delivery commitments
quotes.text: Yeah, so the first phase we just call generally discovery. The second phase, we call solutioning. The third phase, build. And then, the fourth phase is launch, measure and iterate.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A simple, reusable product development lifecycle framework that can be used as planning “gates” for roadmaps and commitments.

quotes.topic_title: Planning cadence, roadmaps, and delivery commitments
quotes.text: Yeah, exactly. You got it.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Confirms a phased-roadmap approach where a quarter can commit to discovery, with subsequent quarters contingent on outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy artifacts and product team tool stack
quotes.text: We have a couple of different layers of this. I think the first is this high-level three-year strategy and this is actually called at the company level.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Highlights a layered approach to strategy artifacts, starting with a company-level 3-year strategy as the top layer.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy artifacts and product team tool stack
quotes.text: So, if the doc, it also has slides that have been presented many times to the company when we're in the process of making sure that, that is part of new hire orientation so that everyone should understand where are we going over the next three years and then therefore how does this year's objectives fit into that.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Shows an operational tactic: repeatedly presenting strategy and embedding it into onboarding to align yearly objectives to long-term direction.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy artifacts and product team tool stack
quotes.text: And then, from there, we've got our product team OKRs. These generally start by docs and we write them in docs. So, they usually get translated into slides at some point for presentation purposes to the company and those are stored centrally in a location and then you get down to the feature level or the project level.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Provides a practical workflow for OKRs and communication: draft in docs, convert to slides for sharing, store centrally, then cascade to project level.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy artifacts and product team tool stack
quotes.text: And we have different kind of templates for the teams to use based on the type of work that they're going to be doing. And we're a pretty heavy Confluence culture, so we tend to use Confluence as one of the tools for housing and storing information around the work that's being done.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Emphasizes standardizing execution with work-type-specific templates and a single source of truth for documentation.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy artifacts and product team tool stack
quotes.text: Then actually roadmap tracking, we use Aha and we use Airtable collaboration/communication. We use Slack, we use Loom, bug management, we use Jira.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Gives concrete examples of a product tool stack mapped to specific jobs-to-be-done (tracking, collaboration, async comms, bug management).

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: getting Calendly’s first users
quotes.text: And so, he was very used to the challenges of trying to organize external meetings with prospective customers. So, he knew the problem space really, really well.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Highlights the advantage of building from deep, firsthand domain pain—especially from a role (sales) that lives the problem daily.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: getting Calendly’s first users
quotes.text: And he had evaluated all the scheduling solutions that were on the market and came to conclusion that there really weren't any great products out there and especially there weren't any great products for the recipient of the actual booking service.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A positioning insight: differentiate by optimizing for the “recipient” experience, not just the person sending invites.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: getting Calendly’s first users
quotes.text: So, he raided his 401k, he took out all his savings. He didn't make raise any money.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: A concrete example of bootstrapping and committing to early execution without external funding.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: getting Calendly’s first users
quotes.text: Why it's important is that the first 10 users were actually customer success agents at a company in the education space that contracted with the same firm that Tope was using to build Calendly. So, he really found his first set of users through the firm that he was using to build the product.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Counterintuitive early-growth channel: leverage your vendors/partners as a distribution path to seed initial users.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: getting Calendly’s first users
quotes.text: And so, then those parents started using Calendly for their own parent-teacher conference scheduling. And then from there, the school started using it and then all the parents within the school started using it for lots of other use cases and it grew organically from there.
quotes.speaker: Annie Pearl
quotes.context: Shows an organic adoption chain (CSMs → parents → school → broader parent community) that practitioners can emulate by designing for shareable workflows.
